document.title: Environmental systems and societies guide (first assessment 2017)

14067C3266C441448CF4F94B00AFDB2A.description: Evaluate how EVSs impact the EFs of individuals or populations.

E8375EBF5CCB407BAFC63A7E07986C12.description: Compare and contrast the differences in the EF of two countries.

E03B181025EB460093B9AB92AF8EBDD0.description: Evaluate the application of carrying capacity to local and global human populations.

96F442C301B9458D80BC670A7E14CAE1.description: If human populations do not live sustainably, they will exceed carrying capacity and risk collapse.

6F884C9968104CA88F79F96212D7A4E4.description: Degradation of the environment, together with the consumption of finite resources, is expected to limit human population growth.

70064DABABD04F21BEF57DA253308D5A.description: EFs may vary significantly by country and by individual and include aspects such as lifestyle choices (EVS), productivity of food production systems, land use and industry. If the EF of a human population is greater than the land area available to it, this indicates that the population is unsustainable and exceeds the carrying capacity of that area.

19D7707E3C86446CBF73B64C68110D97.description: EF is a model used to estimate the demands that human populations place on the environment.

9FD36562047D4618AE4A78AE3DB9CBF1.description: An ecological footprint (EF) is the area of land and water required to provide all resources and assimilate all the waste for a given population. If the EF is greater than the area of land and water available to that population, then it is not sustainable.

852FFFECEC454802A0CF4B7122B9ED2F.description: It is possible to estimate the carrying capacity of an environment for a given species; however, this is problematic in the case of human populations for a number of reasons.

86069D51D0EE4887B6C639B3D49A4C64.description: Carrying capacity is the maximum number of a species, or “load”, that can be sustainably supported by a given area.

4E69605EC27249C8A2F2DD75FDC44CD8.description: Evaluate, with reference to figure 3, pollution management strategies for SDW by considering recycling, incineration, composting and landfills.

BEC27FEF8D434DD7A66066F4C5AB7C7F.description: Compare and contrast pollution management strategies for SDW.

0371EC0AC0F1490292E05BB43104BCE8.description: There are a variety of strategies that can be used to manage SDW (refer to figure 3) influenced by cultural, economic, technological and political barriers. These strategies include: 1) altering human activity—for example, through a reduction of consumption and composting of food waste; 2) controlling the release of pollutant—governments create legislation to encourage recycling and reuse initiatives and impose taxes for SDW collection and on disposable items; 3) reclaiming landfills, using SDW for waste-to-energy programmes, implementing initiatives to remove plastics from the Great Pacific garbage patch (clean-up and restoration).

D22F0D3A038748ED8F147FBA2383380A.description: Waste disposal options include landfills, incineration, recycling and composting.

B6A0D648868A4D6598128F5B542505E0.description: The abundance and prevalence of non-biodegradable pollution (such as plastic, batteries or e-waste) in particular has become a major environmental issue

0CF18AA3AD774C6EBE1F64963FBB791B.description: There are different types of SDW, the volume and composition of which changes over time.

07DEFC5FBCE24E15A7CBF7F032E91C79.description: Explain the dynamic nature of the concept of natural capital.

5FA96676BE2D4F659BDFDA4ACB10759B.description: Outline an example of how renewable and non-renewable natural capital has been mismanaged.

0CF2B4684C0945CFB6C56C4A50950AE5.description: The concept of a natural capital is dynamic. Whether or not something has the status of natural capital, and the marketable value of that capital varies regionally and over time and is influenced by cultural, social, economic, environmental, technological and political factors. Examples include cork, uranium and lithium.

4FF905CBDEC84F8293123E65B72EF79F.description: Natural capital provides goods (such as tangible products) and services (such as climate regulation) that have value. This value may be aesthetic, cultural, economic, environmental, ethical, intrinsic, social, spiritual or technological.

D295F077CA8A4CF0BC0F1BDFEB04DA12.description: The impacts of extraction, transport and processing of a renewable natural capital may cause damage, making this natural capital unsustainable.

1B278A0EE21147FD84EFA810CA1DEDFB.description: Renewable natural capital can be utilized sustainably or unsustainably. If renewable natural capital is used beyond its natural income this use becomes unsustainable.

9C0292027D464C41BDCC3E129881B973.description: Non-renewable natural capital is either irreplaceable or can only be replaced over geological timescales; for example, fossil fuels, soil and minerals.

6FCAD95997D34756BA86317DC340C8DB.description: Renewable natural capital can be generated and/or replaced as fast as it is being used. It includes living species and ecosystems that use solar energy and photosynthesis, as well as non-living items, such as groundwater and the ozone layer.

EF989AB05A1C487399D881741C574DCF.description: Discuss the cultural, historical, religious, social, political and economic factors that influence human population dynamics.

F5B7189BA2044D78BB1127334B39DDBC.description: Analyse the impact that national and international development policies can have on human population dynamics and growth.

53200CF27175476F8CE9239550903793.description: Explain the nature and implications of growth in human populations.

8BAF4C891ED043618799E3EC2A387A42.description: Discuss the use of models in predicting the growth of human populations.

B0C3DE17B1664A13835BC9D7CAD6EA56.description: Analyse age–gender pyramids and diagrams showing demographic transition models.

18B61CB5FF4240098E75BE6D6F9CFEBA.description: Explain the relative values of CBR, CDR, TFR, DT and NIR.

41610E3571C6427CB8B2A3462D17EFB3.description: Calculate values of CBR, CDR, TFR, DT and NIR.

7F1772D5DB664247839BB79E8C29D2AE.description: National and international development policies may also have an impact on human population dynamics.

2035C888550D470DAAAA7AAF61ADE7BA.description: Influences on human population dynamics include cultural, historical, religious, social, political and economic factors.

E481929548F246338C0F3F2F2595DF30.description: Age–gender pyramids and demographic transition models (DTM) can be useful in the prediction of human population growth. The DTM is a model that shows how a population transitions from a pre-industrial stage with high CBRs and CDRs to an economically advanced stage with low or declining CBRs and low CDRs.

C821E1E112C14297855F758DF5CDE516.description: As the human population grows, increased stress is placed on all of the Earth’s systems.

38E5E76B562F4F73A92AF23A6A0A8569.description: Global human population has followed a rapid growth curve, but there is uncertainty as to how this may be changing.

FF73C1B3E5754A8CAC6E384FCC4C97D2.description: Demographic tools for quantifying human population include crude birth rate (CBR), crude death rate (CDR), total fertility rate (TFR), doubling time (DT) and natural increase rate (NIR).

7B73627D81D54A5781C75701BDA7789C.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of international climate change talks.

3C8B2556AD0341B8B8FEE937AEFCD0E5.description: Discuss mitigation and adaptation strategies to deal with impacts of climate change.

959DB861B07F46319B3249F9CD3FE512.description: There are international efforts and conferences to address mitigation and adaptation strategies for climate change; for example, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs) and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).

6CF8809CE62E4088ACBDFD35832241D1.description: Adaptive capacity varies from place to place and can be dependent on financial and technological resources. MEDCs can provide economic and technological support to LEDCs.

26AF3D561EA1491DA69F0585D37C4685.description: Adaptation strategies can be used to reduce adverse affects and maximize any positive effects. Examples of adaptations include flood defences, vaccination programmes, desalinization plants and planting of crops in previously unsuitable climates.

158C383E6F10416E817659E7BBC1516C.description: Even if mitigation strategies drastically reduce future emissions of GHGs, past emissions will continue to have an effect for decades to come.

D307AD31ABF04D1C8059F71A0C6BC065.description: Mitigation strategies for carbon dioxide removal (CDR techniques) include: 1) protecting and enhancing carbon sinks through land management; for example, through the UN collaborative programme on reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in developing countries (UN-REDD); 2) using biomass as a fuel source; 3) using carbon capture and storage (CCS); 4) enhancing carbon dioxide absorption by the oceans through either fertilizing oceans with compounds of nitrogen, phosphorus and iron to encourage the biological pump, or increasing upwellings to release nutrients to the surface.

EED8C7A8FE62415889A33EFA463252C7.description: Mitigation strategies to reduce GHGs in general may include: 1) reduction of energy consumption; 2) reduction of emissions of oxides of nitrogen and methane from agriculture; 3) use of alternatives to fossil fuels; 4) geo-engineering.

A859AFFCCC764D16BC04585E1B2AE957.description: Mitigation involves reduction and/or stabilization of GHG emissions and their removal from the atmosphere.

9EBC0D8A26994946BF9517860FFBCEE9.description: Evaluate contrasting viewpoints on the issue of climate change.

3E2140E55FD74B0F94A9EDB314BCB5C9.description: Discuss the feedback mechanisms that would be associated with a change in mean global temperature.

1BD12E92E2514F60977B371A98D6A915.description: Global climate models are complex and there is a degree of uncertainty regarding the accuracy of their predictions.

57F1B0EFFD684DAD97E83AA15FC354D9.description: There has been significant debate due to conflicting EVSs surrounding the issue of climate change.

C021DC8E348D4A8B91E8CD48810B93B3.description: Both negative and positive feedback mechanisms are associated with climate change and may involve very long time lags.

577AE144FA124A0F81029AF81F87E675.description: The potential impacts of climate change may vary from one location to another and may be perceived as either adverse or beneficial. These impacts may include changes in water availability, distribution of biomes and crop growing areas, loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services, coastal inundation, ocean acidification, and damage to human health.

C8FD5B054DCF4FD89696EF3B42F09AAB.description: Human activities are increasing levels of greenhouse gases (GHGs, such as carbon dioxide, methane and water vapour) in the atmosphere, which leads to: 1) an increase in the mean global temperature; 2)  increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events; 3) the potential for long-term changes in climate and weather patterns; 4) rise in sea level.

B42B0F7632694A1A9E70CF99203F2C97.description: Weather and climate are affected by oceanic and atmospheric circulatory systems.

4C62B854844F4A4280C0C55A6D81D59E.description: Climate describes how the atmosphere behaves over relatively long periods of time, whereas weather describes the conditions in the atmosphere over a short period of time.

8BC5DDCFC9EB41A692EF89553BF7A2EA.description: Evaluate the energy strategy of a given society.

ECF6E9D9E25544F68A229DD0E327958E.description: Discuss the factors that affect energy security.

B5189E0A9592491CA7134DEDE97E6338.description: Discuss the factors that affect the choice of energy sources adopted by different societies.

E113AA7768B946908C2E9A9C53BF42EF.description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of different energy sources.

6A0A46F26C1B48AE9BB53B8A0EC2F0E4.description: Improvements in energy efficiencies and energy conservation can limit growth in energy demand and contribute to energy security.

8595B6CED758400AA066FF24791E176D.description: The energy choices adopted by a society may be influenced by availability; sustainability; scientific and technological developments; cultural attitudes; and political, economic and environmental factors. These in turn affect energy security and independence.

36FEDD7165E94938BC1E4CAC43B9B00B.description: Energy security depends on adequate, reliable and affordable supply of energy that provides a degree of independence. An inequitable availability and uneven distributions of energy sources may lead to conflict.

848EBB0B489F4070A204E813704434D1.description: Sources of energy with lower carbon dioxide emissions than fossil fuels include renewable energy (solar, biomass, hydropower, wind, wave, tidal and geothermal) and their use is expected to increase. Nuclear power is a low-carbon low-emission non-renewable resource but is controversial due to the radioactive waste it produces and the potential scale of any accident.

3A792FD4A3FA45AD99115A1E62B65E2B.description: Fossil fuels contribute to the majority of humankind’s energy supply, and they vary widely in the impacts of their production and their emissions; their use is expected to increase to meet global energy demand.

B8D3ADD8DE6549D393A6969F0425C5D0.description: Evaluate pollution management strategies for acid deposition.

E1C739BE1E6D4EAD89C77029800E25BC.description: Clean-up and restoration measures may include spreading ground limestone in acidified lakes or recolonization of damaged systems—but the scope of these measures is limited.

1A62EE121BBA44D6A1E07F4DE02BECAA.description: Pollution management strategies for acid deposition could include: 1) altering human activity—for example, through reducing use, or using alternatives to, fossil fuels; international agreements and national governments may work to reduce pollutant production through lobbying; 2) regulating and monitoring the release of pollutants—for example, through the use of scrubbers or catalytic converters that may remove sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen from coal-burning powerplants and cars.

698C8D468A374F808737FA8183E7CAD6.description: The impacts of acid deposition may be limited to areas downwind of major industrial regions but these areas may not be in the same country as the source of emissions.

690742B08BD54E85B405FEFE247AB773.description: The possible effects of acid deposition on soil, water and living organisms include: 1) direct effect—for example, acid on aquatic organisms and coniferous forests; 2) indirect toxic effect—for example, increased solubility of metal (such as aluminium ions) on fish; 3) indirect nutrient effect—for example, leaching of plant nutrients.

DB89B8DCA01341FCAD00BCF5328C516A.description: The combustion of fossil fuels produces sulfur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen as primary pollutants. These gases may be converted into secondary pollutants of dry deposition (such as ash and dry particles) or wet deposition (such as rain and snow).

9D02D529DB6642329ACCDA0685229ECE.description: Evaluate pollution management strategies for reducing photochemical smog.

F6FA13D6D79E4A2AA131EBF836BC167C.description: Pollution management strategies include: 1) altering human activity to consume less fossil fuels—example activities include the purchase of energy-efficient technologies, the use of public or shared transit, and walking or cycling; 2) regulating and reducing pollutants at the point of emission through government regulation or taxation; 3) using catalytic converters to clean the exhaust of primary pollutants from car exhaust; 4) regulating fuel quality by governments; 5) adopting clean-up measures such as reforestation, regreening, and conservation of areas to sequester carbon dioxide.

6AFD8C1AF24B45BCA740199517C228B4.description: Economic losses caused by urban air pollution can be significant.

C67D6F82AA204050B741BFC3FD08C026.description: Deforestation and burning may also contribute to smog.

3CDD6E4B4F2540B0B384BEBF59FFA09F.description: Thermal inversions occur due to a lack of air movement when a layer of dense, cool air is trapped beneath a layer of less dense, warm air. This causes concentrations of air pollutants to build up near the ground instead of being dissipated by “normal” air movements.

58D31E4CB1BE43A0BB7A911F694A0E30.description: The frequency and severity of smog in an area depends on local topography, climate, population density, and fossil fuel use.

F75AFE7FE26845B4AD0E3AF302163239.description: Tropospheric ozone is highly reactive and damages plants (crops and forests), irritates eyes, creates respiratory illnesses and damages fabrics and rubber materials. Smog is a complex mixture of primary and secondary pollutants, of which tropospheric ozone is the main pollutant.

391009DBB6B64552AA005D919C2A933B.description: Tropospheric ozone is an example of a secondary pollutant, formed when oxygen molecules react with oxygen atoms that are released from nitrogen dioxide in the presence of sunlight.

B37EF41EF18548AC8D8EF9D720E50E62.description: In the presence of sunlight, secondary pollutants are formed when primary pollutants undergo a variety of reactions with other chemicals already present in the atmosphere.

E1BE942622A04819A2E3EF701E5F5CA1.description: Primary pollutants from the combustion of fossil fuels include carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, black carbon or soot, unburned hydrocarbons, oxides of nitrogen, and oxides of sulfur.

4B76ECC1D07D4EDBBB35FA0E12F3E15C.description: Evaluate the role of national and international organizations in reducing the emissions of ozone-depleting substances.

FE9D997E962942D694FA5DE3544E69E9.description: The Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer (1987) and subsequent updates is an international agreement for the reduction of use of ozone-depleting substances signed under the direction of UNEP. National governments complying with the agreement made national laws and regulations to decrease the consumption and production of halogenated organic gases such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

DFB2ED1AF02A4D77842275B0CAE980B5.description: An illegal market for ozone-depleting substances persists and requires consistent monitoring.

4644B91CA9BE46C484CD365513CE3FD3.description: UNEP has had a key role in providing information, and creating and evaluating international agreements, for the protection of stratospheric ozone.

60BF319BF6F4466F9B1C4F65F6055CC6.description: Pollution management may be achieved by reducing the manufacture and release of ozone-depleting substances. Methods for this reduction include: 1) recycling refrigerants; 2) developing alternatives to gas-blown plastics, halogenated pesticides, propellants and aerosols developing non-propellant alternatives.

4D662F905FCA4A2AB5BEE8928E09053B.description: The effects of increased ultraviolet radiation on biological productivity include damage to photosynthetic organisms, especially phytoplankton, which form the basis of aquatic food webs.

CDC5187BDDC4493D82C1589570C3B762.description: Ultraviolet radiation reaching the surface of the Earth damages human living tissues, increasing the incidence of cataracts, mutation during cell division, skin cancer and other subsequent effects on health.

B7EC504CC51C4923ADAB561841EF0664.description: Ozone depleting substances (including halogenated organic gases such as chlorofluorocarbons—CFCs) are used in aerosols, gas-blown plastics, pesticides, flame retardants and refrigerants. Halogen atoms (such as chlorine) from these pollutants increase destruction of ozone in a repetitive cycle, allowing more ultraviolet radiation to reach the Earth.

FA5AD79ABBEB4675856F340341DCAC08.description: Some ultraviolet radiation from the Sun is absorbed by stratospheric ozone causing the ozone molecule to break apart. Under normal conditions the ozone molecule will reform. This ozone destruction and reformation is an example of a dynamic equilibrium.

D4AE27AF2534428BA5ADF279510C779E.description: Outline the role of the greenhouse effect in regulating temperature on Earth.

277B938F2BAF42D793612911A22761CB.description: Discuss the role of the albedo effect from clouds in regulating global average temperature.

61D2E58ED86040F1984335C12A887088.description: The greenhouse effect of the atmosphere is a natural and necessary phenomenon maintaining suitable temperatures for living systems.

17B91EF1B2744D169EA4E2264428D9FD.description: Most clouds form in the troposphere and play an important role in the albedo effect of the planet.

C6D2330AAAFE4EC5B71A8583F6A29CB7.description: Most reactions connected to living systems occur in the inner layers of the atmosphere, which are the troposphere (0–10 km above sea level) and the stratosphere (10–50 km above sea level).

60C03F2CA1744BF0A35467D6F4057775.description: Human activities impact atmospheric composition through altering inputs and outputs of the system. Changes in the concentrations of atmospheric gases—such as ozone, carbon dioxide, and water vapour—have significant effects on ecosystems.

8DBC78479E3C4EEA99B9F4DD83CE41F2.description: The atmosphere is predominantly a mixture of nitrogen and oxygen, with smaller amounts of carbon dioxide, argon, water vapour and other trace gases.

D4E026E0432C44DAB0E12167261A1995.description: The atmosphere is a dynamic system (with inputs, outputs, flows and storages) that has undergone changes throughout geological time.

593CD56E545341A59CF0B5CCD9DB39D0.description: Evaluate the soil management strategies of a given commercial farming system and of a given subsistence farming system.

65379B91F0E3415DAB15BA246F1B277B.description: Discuss the influences of human activities on soil fertility and soil erosion.

A77D89D7CC064FDEABF051E2BBFB1C6B.description: Explain the relationship between soil ecosystem succession and soil fertility.

8F180A9DC39B4067A81CC998AB6CD093.description: Soil conservation measures include soil conditioners (such as organic materials and lime), wind reduction techniques (wind breaks, shelter belts), cultivation techniques (terracing, contour ploughing, strip cultivation) and avoiding the use of marginal lands.

50EF39DD97364C24B78138E1FBE1EBA4.description: Reduced soil fertility may result in soil erosion, toxification, salination and desertification.

822A9D7DD9574875ABCA4B33BED2B832.description: Commercial, industrialized food production systems generally tend to reduce soil fertility more than small-scale subsistence farming methods.

8CA23303A7B6408B832E4FC2B6BCD3C6.description: Human activities that can reduce soil fertility include deforestation, intensive grazing, urbanization and certain agricultural practices (such as irrigation and monoculture).

4D65D6A77F724B54A736B22A8C774175.description: Soil ecosystems change through succession. Fertile soil contains a community of organisms that work to maintain functioning nutrient cycles and that are resistant to soil erosion.

BDE5DEBEEC464A08A0C0398A730E0820.description: Evaluate strategies to increase sustainability in terrestrial food production systems.

AE33A984DEC84467ACF5E9BDF925DFB8.description: Discuss the links that exist between sociocultural systems and food production systems.

61C84ED23ECF431C88C8269D3E9CFF50.description: Evaluate the relative environmental impacts of two given food production systems.

2ADF8BA6D59D4309979AFDDB5F07D081.description: Compare and contrast the inputs, outputs and system characteristics for two given food production systems.

A8ED6A47E2D44EFBA8D479DCDB3DBBA1.description: Analyse tables and graphs that illustrate the differences in inputs and outputs associated with food production systems.

D710632891C043DCACED9F1D618396D5.description: Increased sustainability may be achieved through: 1) altering human activity to reduce meat consumption and increase consumption of organically grown and locally produced terrestrial food products; 2) improving the accuracy of food labels to assist consumers in making informed food choices; 3) monitoring and control of the standards and practices of multinational and national food corporations by governmental and intergovernmental bodies; 4) planting of buffer zones around land suitable for food production to absorb nutrient runoff.

C249400126984011B0FDD7FD53C03AFD.description: Terrestrial food production systems can be compared and contrasted according to inputs, outputs, system characteristics, environmental impact and socio-economic factors.

1BF9752E50C2493491FA3FCA767EE418.description: Cultural choices may influence societies to harvest food from higher trophic levels.

FEBDBF5F3D9146C58644D75807F454EB.description: The yield of food per unit area from lower trophic levels is greater in quantity, lower in cost and may require fewer resources.

4C6198BF81B84B82A02DD279D16A9A61.description: As the human population grows, along with urbanization and degradation of soil resources, the availability of land for food production per capita decreases.

775FAA3D7BBA443B82A0C28604F5AAEB.description: Socio-economic, cultural, ecological, political and economic factors can be seen to influence societies in their choices of food production systems.

8C328EF082B24E70BAB65EA741D1A9FF.description: Food waste is prevalent in both LEDCs and more economically developed countries (MEDCs), but for different reasons.

7DDF46374D194595BBFAFB300B4649A7.description: Inequalities exist in food production and distribution around the world.

0AB30684A32045E0AE781B5547064D49.description: The sustainability of terrestrial food production systems is influenced by factors such as scale; industrialization; mechanization; fossil fuel use; seed, crop and livestock choices; water use; fertilizers; pest control; pollinators; antibiotics; legislation; and levels of commercial versus subsistence food production.

11A0FB047FEA4884AABF828099656F41.description: Terrestrial food production systems and food choices

0DB1B4620B7346DF8CFC3AB4C3F5BFC2.description: Compare and contrast the structure and properties of sand, clay and loam soils, with reference to a soil texture diagram, including their effect on primary productivity.

0395664A00A749D2AD70F7DCB750A8D9.description: Explain how soil can be viewed as an ecosystem.

3AA969F4E8A64598B09EE9A6C908495D.description: Outline the transfers, transformations, inputs, outputs, flows and storages within soil systems.

0BF7C564521F404A82734DBBB7D2E750.description: A soil texture triangle illustrates the differences in composition of soils.

58CC22C48E094402AC159AB94C7B8770.description: The structure and properties of sand, clay and loam soils differ in many ways, including mineral and nutrient content, drainage, water-holding capacity, air spaces, biota and potential to hold organic matter. Each of these variables is linked to the ability of the soil to promote primary productivity.

32D3F8717C434757B54CA36F3912B27F.description: Transformations include decomposition, weathering and nutrient cycling.

A1EC7BAC5F4749B78DD253FADF988B34.description: There are inputs of organic material including leaf litter and inorganic matter from parent material, precipitation and energy. Outputs include uptake by plants and soil erosion.

B82F30156B764CF8AA11FD16B57994EF.description: Transfers of material within the soil, including biological mixing and leaching (minerals dissolved in water moving through soil), contribute to the organization of the soil.

D522DF091BB34DACA555DA46FA6F97CF.description: Soil system storages include organic matter, organisms, nutrients, minerals, air and water.

9BD247675546420DB171237F7757E0CE.description: The soil system may be illustrated by a soil profile that has a layered structure (horizons).

D1D7642216694700B7E2B16A7C8ED3D9.description: Soil systems and terrestrial food production systems and societies

F7F087D289324502B63DA494B2B1622B.description: Evaluate pollution management strategies with respect to water pollution.

0BE5EAA108874351A7BD0F512193F1BC.description: Evaluate the uses of indicator species and biotic indices in measuring aquatic pollution.

BA49CD65CAA443328629C7F5C2CEA1FB.description: Explain the process and impacts of eutrophication.

79ED948A468246F39AB4EB65B64ABB5F.description: Application of water pollution management strategies includes: 1) reducing human activities that produce pollutants (for example, alternatives to current fertilizers and detergents); 2) reducing release of pollution into the environment (for example, treatment of waste water to remove nitrates and phosphates); 3) removing pollutants from the environment and restoring ecosystems (for example, removal of mud from eutrophic lakes and reintroduction of plant and fish species).

9A88619C32134969B0F2A176B9C86A32.description: Dead zones in both oceans and fresh water can occur when there is not enough oxygen to support marine life.

E5C107A61B9845B2AAA92952EE5EAE79.description: Eutrophication can occur when lakes, estuaries and coastal waters receive inputs of nutrients (nitrates and phosphates), which results in an excess growth of plants and phytoplankton.

92466D1978F0400D83B178BE7676A560.description: A biotic index indirectly measures pollution by assaying the impact on species within the community according to their tolerance, diversity and relative abundance.

91A88E4CB8D2412883ECEFD6069F7719.description: Some species can be indicative of polluted waters and can be used as indicator species.

86F4B76750D04B48BA9744E8A9611F1C.description: Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a measure of the amount of dissolved oxygen required to break down the organic material in a given volume of water through aerobic biological activity. BOD is used to indirectly measure the amount of organic matter within a sample.

2D79417E041E4F32BCD9F6268F55A809.description: Biodegradation of organic material utilizes oxygen, which can lead to anoxic conditions and subsequent anaerobic decomposition, which in turn leads to formation of methane, hydrogen sulfide and ammonia (toxic gases).

39AE9E6676A045C2A6B0F870ABE6390D.description: A wide range of parameters can be used to directly test the quality of aquatic systems, including pH, temperature, suspended solids (turbidity), metals, nitrates and phosphates.

30DAC5417015497689B647F77B8FD553.description: Types of aquatic pollutants include floating debris, organic material, inorganic plant nutrients (nitrates and phosphates), toxic metals, synthetic compounds, suspended solids, hot water, oil, radioactive pollution, pathogens, light, noise and biological pollutants (invasive species).

31910205211C4E30BD4D588ECA3D4733.description: There are a variety of freshwater and marine pollution sources.

C3320A0B0132416882963FC06151A082.description: Discuss a case study that demonstrates the impact of aquaculture.

679EA3D1347B44DDBCC47233762137E0.description: Explain the potential value of aquaculture for providing food for future generations.

9D188D1952484D1FA1630C76F7A88F8B.description: Evaluate strategies that can be used to avoid

ED27B2A6E1664C1DA9042DEA57FC4C89.description: Discuss, with reference to a case study, the controversial harvesting of a named species.

42A43869F5B2484CA4B9B8198B5388DA.description: Issues around aquaculture include: loss of habitats, pollution (with feed, antifouling agents, antibiotics and other medicines added to fish pens), spread of diseases and escaped species (some involving genetically modified organisms).

A475F63D760648C8B58D73CF6B6E3BD9.description: Aquaculture has grown to provide additional food resources and support economic development and is expected to continue to rise.

DC03262BCC374C6C888D1BE46F3DDB1A.description: Unsustainable exploitation of aquatic systems can be mitigated at a variety of levels (international, national, local and individual) through policy, legislation and changes in consumer behaviour.

C294221EE50A46A3884C58EC1543979C.description: Developments in fishing equipment and changes to fishing methods have led to dwindling fish stocks and damage to habitats.

49D6C211D2904FC4BE0AF55F19F14226.description: Harvesting some species, such as seals and whales, can be controversial. Ethical issues arise over biorights, rights of indigenous cultures and international conservation legislation.

4B0156D905764FC5917AFE3A1C31C92D.description: The highest rates of productivity are found near coastlines or in shallow seas, where upwellings and nutrient enrichment of surface waters occurs.

1AEC71356BB946CF8ED89A09887BE6C8.description: Aquatic (freshwater and marine) flora and fauna are harvested by humans.

61C43577A2E94721B8C786195E245954.description: Photosynthesis by phytoplankton supports a highly diverse range of food webs.

76F4ADD5BC9D4341829E7BC590E44F62.description: Demand for aquatic food resources continues to increase as human population grows and diet changes.

401EA6ADA4C94AC58752C154B2493695.description: Discuss, with reference to a case study, how shared freshwater resources have given rise to international conflict.

6A15FD0E4F5741A9BC39EF78F80FAC48.description: Evaluate the strategies that can be used to meet an increasing demand for fresh water.

E918D86408E84BD8B9C6D4A7F9AD67A7.description: The scarcity of water resources can lead to conflict between human populations, particularly where sources are shared.

001CA4103CC949DDB06468CAA3EB60CC.description: Water supplies can be enhanced through reservoirs, redistribution, desalination, artificial recharge of aquifers and rainwater harvesting schemes. Water conservation (including grey-water recycling) can help to reduce demand but often requires a change in attitude by the water consumers.

7BBC4535789149DB977AEF5B5E8EB0CB.description: Freshwater supplies may become limited through contamination and unsustainable abstraction.

F32F4A511C7D4706927DC1B39876317E.description: As populations, irrigation and industrialization increase, the demand for fresh water increases.

E072B8599EB6455FB009ACE4B0309D98.description: Climate change may disrupt rainfall patterns and further affect this access.

9CC645BC5BA24AE5B020EE2A92887830.description: Access to an adequate freshwater supply varies widely.

0EFCCF1593E8420C80B3B56682AD25E1.description: Construct and analyse a hydrological cycle diagram.

A7863B11C90B4A608FBF848C49E994A3.description: Discuss human impact on the hydrological cycle.

DFE30CE13AA240DE8821720CB6A44372.description: Ocean circulation systems are driven by differences in temperature and salinity. The resulting difference in water density drives the ocean conveyor belt, which distributes heat around the world, and thus affects climate.

C3132FD638154A018D44898B1AD30B7C.description: Human activities such as agriculture, deforestation and urbanization have a significant impact on surface runoff and infiltration.

838F116F1902468CAF9762B76EE489CC.description: Flows in the hydrological cycle include evapotranspiration, sublimation, evaporation, condensation, advection (wind-blown movement), precipitation, melting, freezing, flooding, surface runoff, infiltration, percolation, and stream-flow or currents.

010E514F24014F759354D80766FF8E5C.description: Storages in the hydrological cycle include organisms, soil and various water bodies, including oceans, groundwater (aquifers), lakes, rivers, atmosphere, glaciers and ice caps.

BFF382AAB0B34DA0B835C1DF16B9E0AF.description: Fresh water makes up only a small fraction (approximately 2.6% by volume) of the Earth’s water storages.

7F2C6EAA1C1D43DC8C729BC26F5EC927.description: Solar radiation drives the hydrological cycle.

8D6836644EC743F4B42672265CD7A8AD.description: Water and aquatic food production systems and societies

79E66C45A30940B5BE27E703CE06BA82.description: Evaluate different approaches to protecting biodiversity.

FDA72FFCE45347F383EE79A6D0401210.description: Evaluate the success of a given protected area.

B6B1D5A68E294BB0907D4B79F54B096C.description: Explain the criteria used to design and manage protected areas.

CED8962E6B1147BE923E1FEE8210063E.description: The location of a conservation area in a country is a significant factor in the success of the conservation effort. Surrounding land use for the conservation area and distance from urban centres are important factors for consideration in conservation area design.

0A993E9D64074C73887541FEDFC92E68.description: Community support, adequate funding and proper research influence the success of conservation efforts.

38F746875EE5447FA4A6C9E41AE4D80C.description: Alternative approaches to the development of protected areas are species-based conservation strategies including: 1) CITES; 2) captive breeding and reintroduction programmes, and zoos; 3) selection of “charismatic” species to help protect others in an area (flagship species); 4) selection of keystone species to protect the integrity of the food web.

64C6CD6EA8F5457F9B3BD145957C8677.description: Criteria for consideration when designing protected areas include size, shape, edge effects, corridors, and proximity to potential human influence.

CAA100A875924B88A178CC358EB8AAA7.description: Conservation approaches include habitat conservation, species-based conservation and a mixed approach.

92434B697E284FDB90457181C2470299.description: Recent international conventions on biodiversity work to create collaboration between nations for biodiversity conservation.

2F3190156B464AA194FD80F26F5BDF64.description: International, governmental and non‑governmental organizations (NGOs) are involved in conserving and restoring ecosystems and biodiversity, with varying levels of effectiveness due to their use of media, speed of response, diplomatic constraints, financial resources and political influence.

9176BC3E69564D01AA0410D7CEA58752.description: Arguments about species and habitat preservation can be based on aesthetic, ecological, economic, ethical and social justifications.

C701E65C20684BA88D858590A30D4759.description: Discuss the conflict between exploitation, sustainable development and conservation in tropical biomes.

AC2A965B5EC5414A9442B5A165C48E27.description: Evaluate the impact of human activity on the biodiversity of tropical biomes.

CA73FA7005AE4847A7EACA6A9EB6FCF4.description: Describe the threats to biodiversity from human activity in a given natural area of biological significance or conservation area.

8C2CA58E0D7B4DAAB7D39BF63767E895.description: Discuss the case histories of three different species: one that has become extinct due to human activity, another that is critically endangered, and a third species whose conservation status has been improved by intervention.

41C923F5C07B458AA2407DEAD7D0598A.description: Most tropical biomes occur in less economically developed countries (LEDCs) and therefore there is conflict between exploitation, sustainable development and conservation.

7A75F36A6BB44F1DA9E903957D5C9D04.description: Tropical biomes contain some of the most globally biodiverse areas and their unsustainable exploitation results in massive losses in biodiversity and their ability to perform globally important ecological services.

B47274608A3A485680D9A65F36F80323.description: The International Union of Conservation of Nature (IUCN) publishes data in the “Red List of Threatened Species” in several categories. Factors used to determine the conservation status of a species include: population size, degree of specialization, distribution, reproductive potential and behaviour, geographic range and degree of fragmentation, quality of habitat, trophic level, and the probability of extinction.

2EB565225EF94A6A8055BE4089F138E6.description: The current rates of species loss are far greater now than in the recent past, due to increased human influence. The human activities that cause species extinctions include habitat destruction, introduction of invasive species, pollution, overharvesting and hunting.

E120FEA0411C482784E8BA679036AD6F.description: Estimates of the total number of species on Earth vary considerably. They are based on mathematical models, which are influenced by classification issues and a lack of finance for scientific research, resulting in many habitats and groups being significantly under-recorded.

76697EA9B82B4F89800A9850BC021293.description: Discuss the causes of mass extinctions.

971E6A0EC5D94DDAB0F4A4B57FB0E249.description: Explain how plate activity has influenced evolution and biodiversity.

248C17DD6E764371879EF12FB254C180.description: Mass extinctions of the past have been caused by various factors, such as tectonic plate movements, super-volcanic eruption, climatic changes (including drought and ice ages), and meteorite impact—all of which resulted in new directions in evolution and therefore increased biodiversity.

937DC8B240E747148E956E65134BB020.description: The distribution of continents has also caused climatic variations and variation in food supply, both contributing to evolution.

A4E2209E6A8D4D53BC157F82F879F567.description: Isolation of populations can be caused by environmental changes forming barriers such as mountain formation, changes in rivers, sea level change, climatic change or plate movements. The surface of the Earth is divided into crustal, tectonic plates that have moved throughout geological time. This has led to the creation of both land bridges and physical barriers with evolutionary consequences.

32E2BCA327444AED9144400677CE350B.description: Speciation is the formation of new species when populations of a species become isolated and evolve differently from other populations.

256A802BE4C14E5682B51F3999AD2CCB.description: Environmental change gives new challenges to species: those that are suited will survive, and those that are not suited will not survive.

CB1189888ED34E52AC7EC81D35C29CF1.description: This natural selection will contribute to the evolution of biodiversity over time.

E4EFA97A780F4B14AC51336929FC6EB9.description: Natural selection occurs through the following mechanism: 1) within a population of one species, there is genetic diversity, which is called variation; 2) due to natural variation, some individuals will be fitter than others; 3) fitter individuals have an advantage and will reproduce more successfully than individuals who are less fit; 4) the offspring of fitter individuals may inherit the genes that give that advantage.

0F4B05084FA94266A1DFA6B9BCE2EA6B.description: Biological variation arises randomly and can either be beneficial to, damaging to, or have no impact on, the survival of the individual.

A22BB90B551B4ADEBA52DB0C357EC330.description: Discuss the usefulness of providing numerical values of species diversity to understanding the nature of biological communities and the conservation of biodiversity.

E006B0F371A1489E90B163AFBDC30589.description: Comment on the relative values of biodiversity data.

22E7748F1954453AABF58A5A697E1EEA.description: Distinguish between biodiversity, diversity of species, habitat diversity and genetic diversity.

FE8E8543D3E84EBEA8F770337B511374.description: The ability to assess changes to biodiversity in a given community over time is important in assessing the impact of human activity in the community.

72D253EBD8804250AF41F271065C767C.description: Quantification of biodiversity is important to conservation efforts so that areas of high biodiversity may be identified, explored, and appropriate conservation put in place where possible.

4573D6FCB49C49E4852A4EC0457D0A00.description: Genetic diversity refers to the range of genetic material present in a population of a species.

194FD0E805D04DC89D6C46C5010D9573.description: Habitat diversity refers to the range of different habitats in an ecosystem or biome.

FBF15319294A4A018737CA72E0B4EE85.description: Communities can be described and compared through the use of diversity indices. When comparing communities that are similar, low diversity could be indicative of pollution, eutrophication or recent colonization of a site. The number of species present in an area is often indicative of general patterns of biodiversity.

03621374967946A6BEA875B65C4F3DFD.description: Species diversity in communities is a product of two variables: the number of species (richness) and their relative proportions (evenness).

D2C4B79786254B9EBC584551857738E3.description: Biodiversity is a broad concept encompassing the total diversity of living systems, which includes the diversity of species, habitat diversity and genetic diversity.

F4E50C12E99B48BF8D3C6A68E566ABB3.description: Draw graphs to illustrate species diversity in a community over time, or between communities.

A05CEE41D2B94577A0A9E906854FC14C.description: Calculate and interpret data for species richness and diversity.

31BB17C27F874B17B5E5999A98D1930C.description: Evaluate methods for measuring or estimating populations of motile and non-motile organisms.

2DB1922E1AE945AD89003DFD5BE27E88.description: Evaluate methods for estimating biomass at different trophic levels in an ecosystem.

30A6218D575540FCB7E4E43EE2D1D76A.description: Evaluate methods to investigate the change along an environmental gradient and the effect of a human impact in an ecosystem.

477D630A7AA04D3C9DBC51C77FBDC088.description: Evaluate methods to measure at least three abiotic factors in an ecosystem.

A2014D3F88354C23AEC819CD4E6E597C.description: Construct simple identification keys for up to eight species.

E437973E27D9495F8D6CD52CF556D064.description: Design and carry out ecological investigations.

3CBA9BD50BB24656B10FD835433C03E5.description: Species diversity is a function of the number of species and their relative abundance and can be compared using an index. There are many versions of diversity indices, but students are only expected to be able to apply and evaluate the result of the Simpson diversity index. Using this formula, the higher the result (D), the greater the species diversity. This indication of diversity is only useful when comparing two similar habitats, or the same habitat over time.

FDDE2C5A7FFB47C29277BFD46169E7FF.description: Species richness is the number of species in a community and is a useful comparative measure.

940F12AC73544E74A3CECA401D581D90.description:
Direct and indirect methods for estimating the abundance of motile organisms can be described and evaluated. Direct methods include actual counts and sampling. Indirect methods include the use of capture–mark–recapture with the application of the Lincoln index.
Lincoln index = n1 x n2 / nm n1 is the number caught in the first sample.
n2 is the number caught in the second sample.
nm is the number caught in the second sample that were marked.

7C73FABBCED14437B02FD940A4CB2DDB.description: Methods for estimating the abundance of non-motile organisms include the use of quadrats for making actual counts, measuring population density, percentage cover and percentage frequency.

37D55737B6714B60803C82671BF3D187.description: Methods for estimating the biomass and energy of trophic levels in a community include measurement of dry mass, controlled combustion and extrapolation from samples. Data from these methods can be used to construct ecological pyramids.

CFFD25AC82D64BAAAD484B92611A67DF.description: Measurements should be repeated to increase reliability of data. The number of repetitions required depends on the factor being measured.

14A8D68FD8DB4D8BBA6E1C0DEC0B57ED.description: Sampling strategies may be used to measure biotic and abiotic factors and their change in space, along an environmental gradient, over time, through succession, or before and after a human impact (for example, as part of an EIA).

1D4CCBCD6C3E4BE5889C4C567ED77EE9.description: Organisms in an ecosystem can be identified using a variety of tools including keys, comparison to herbarium or specimen collections, technologies and scientific expertise.

E8A5F29122D748E9BB26B41D392F7933.description: The study of an ecosystem requires that it be named and located; for example, Deinikerwald in Baar, Switzerland—a mixed deciduous–coniferous managed woodland.

4F84A412DA8642DAAE7BC428BA48514E.description: Interpret models or graphs related to succession and zonation.

9075FA1B66A4467B83A11525A0D9F568.description: Distinguish the roles of r and K selected species in succession.

19EB1C939A574C72A87E83708339FCAC.description: Discuss the link between ecosystem stability, succession, diversity and human activity.

6DF1225A7845478BBA479A4C12798686.description: Discuss the factors that could lead to alternative stable states in an ecosystem.

7FA5CBD5EB4E4932A86F8D0DCDA3B5F1.description: Explain the general patterns of change in communities undergoing succession.

6779A5C3896046C7BBC3554B3CB373CD.description: Describe the process of succession in a given example.

53919CA35D5C41B78894D53E7F07095C.description: Discuss the impact of climate change on biomes.

98A9049169DA4E8C949DEAC3C84F164F.description: Analyse data for a range of biomes.

DB3413BA78E942D7BC6F0A250F89943B.description: Explain the distributions, structure, biodiversity and relative productivity of contrasting biomes.

4305FE58F8B443E7AE89DA5DD2712B89.description: An ecosystem’s capacity to survive change may depend on its diversity and resilience.

8F36178D26834305A85C648E4035A84C.description: Human activity is one factor that can divert the progression of succession to an alternative stable state by modifying the ecosystem; for example, the use of fire in an ecosystem, the use of agriculture, grazing pressure, or resource use (such as deforestation). This diversion may be more or less permanent depending upon the resilience of the ecosystem.

27B21A622AB44879BEFF01CE80470525.description: There is no one climax community, but rather a set of alternative stable states for a given ecosystem. These depend on the climatic factors, the properties of the local soil and a range of random events that can occur over time.

0F32B81A21204A8C8598D601DB306C28.description: In a complex ecosystem, the variety of nutrient and energy pathways contributes to its stability.

EA453B99D1AA4E75BCB7C2CFB2AD2B70.description: In later stages of succession, with an increased consumer community, gross productivity may be high in a climax community. However, this is balanced by respiration, so net productivity approaches 0 and the productivity–respiration (P:R) ratio approaches 1.

EA5AB593D1FD403880D6DD796FA67F1D.description: In early stages of succession, gross productivity is low due to the unfavourable initial conditions and low density of producers. The proportion of energy lost through community respiration is relatively low too, so net productivity is high—that is, the system is growing and biomass is accumulating.

88F63E4B7FF444D88C50ED0E881C179E.description: r- and K-strategist species have reproductive strategies that are better adapted to pioneer and climax communities, respectively.

7A53352F6C994E61AC4E99F31A2EFB10.description: Greater habitat diversity leads to greater species and genetic diversity.

8CC8583F3C3146958F31E6AA3030C6BD.description: During succession, the patterns of energy flow, gross and net productivity, diversity, and mineral cycling change over time.

FF90D1E26CCF4E978DAFA78AA8BE5093.description: Succession is the process of change over time in an ecosystem involving pioneer, intermediate and climax communities.

290F4C8843C84D9C902F6E064FEABC4A.description: Zonation refers to changes in community along an environmental gradient due to factors such as changes in altitude, latitude, tidal level or distance from shore (coverage by water).

62C0CDA2275F41419D4F4EFCAD2DC37D.description: Climate change is altering the distribution of biomes and causing biome shifts.

0616B522D2DE4F148BA50DDDE5D9AADE.description: The tricellular model of atmospheric circulation explains the distribution of precipitation and temperature and how they influence structure and relative productivity of different terrestrial biomes.

0ACCCD2BD82A42B7A9E2E1D28EC1C0AE.description: Insolation, precipitation and temperature are the main factors governing the distribution of biomes.

9F29246C2D4C4853853259F9B4A7AFE1.description: Biomes are collections of ecosystems sharing similar climatic conditions that can be grouped into five major classes: aquatic, forest, grassland, desert and tundra. Each of these classes has characteristic limiting factors, productivity and biodiversity.

6846AA8EB564414BB445378C14ACB520.description: Discuss human impacts on energy flows, and on the carbon and nitrogen cycles.

A2D20A950CEB46BD91306C3DEB211308.description: Calculate the values of both GSP and NSP from given data.

D5146CFE659747A5A0DDF2F50C757EDB.description: Calculate the values of both GPP and NPP from given data.

84CAE08F395F4A74B63B6A4FEE82BEE0.description: Analyse the efficiency of energy transfers through a system.

DEA84E72D57443FD9559D29C1CDE9999.description: Construct a quantitative model of the flows of energy or matter for given data.

A8F8D251F0794939A53FF184BD343702.description: Analyse quantitative models of flows of energy and matter.

41452622230C424A910A4017C3443721.description: Human activities such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, urbanization and agriculture impact energy flows as well as the carbon and nitrogen cycles.

8ECF1531808B40FD9168C990D4916A62.description: Flows in the nitrogen cycle include nitrogen fixation by bacteria and lightning, absorption, assimilation, consumption (feeding), excretion, death and decomposition, and denitrification by bacteria in water-logged soils.

BA2E3A9BE65F45E1815826E2E06A81B4.description: Storages in the nitrogen cycle include organisms (organic), soil, fossil fuels, atmosphere and water bodies (all inorganic).

FF2A6759DAA4480481C2369E5F3728DB.description: Flows in the carbon cycle include consumption (feeding), death and decomposition, photosynthesis, respiration, dissolving and fossilization.

934E2C109A4D4CEEA9C26AE4CAF1E577.description: Storages in the carbon cycle include organisms and forests (both organic), or the atmosphere, soil, fossil fuels and oceans (all inorganic).

30306500AA95422E8B10C631A3628258.description: The carbon and nitrogen cycles are used to illustrate this flow of matter using flow diagrams. These cycles contain storages (sometimes referred to as sinks) and flows, which move matter between storages.

1059FEEAB0874DAAA2ED3F8B0DE567E2.description: Matter also flows through ecosystems linking them together. This flow of matter involves transfers and transformations.

70974AC2BFCF47FF8587B9989C6DBB52.description: Maximum sustainable yields are equivalent to the net primary or net secondary productivity of a system.

8FC9D0BAB4E043988D7DCC17F3427008.description:
Net secondary productivity (NSP) is calculated by subtracting respiratory losses (R) from GSP.
   NSP = GSP – R

B3595031962141E1B5B679F91AA4ACDA.description: Gross secondary productivity (GSP) is the total energy or biomass assimilated by consumers and is calculated by subtracting the mass of fecal loss from the mass of food consumed. GSP = food eaten – fecal loss

2125479AEFDF48EFBF01E5A23AE4067C.description:
Net primary productivity (NPP) is calculated by subtracting respiratory losses (R) from gross primary productivity (GPP).
   NPP = GPP – R

C6ADF47A834A405C8565E69D71FCE790.description: The conversion of energy into biomass for a given period of time is measured as productivity.

E1A522E2A9534827846F31EAEF702B66.description: Pathways of energy through an ecosystem include: 1) conversion of light energy to chemical energy, 2) transfer of chemical energy from one trophic level to another with varying efficiencies, 3) overall conversion of ultraviolet and visible light to heat energy by an ecosystem, 4) re-radiation of heat energy to the atmosphere.

884D6874468F46AC817E79FFEFB12378.description: Pathways of radiation through the atmosphere involve a loss of radiation through reflection and absorption.

73DC4EB623A44F48BFFF83F08CE3B60F.description: As solar radiation (insolation) enters the Earth’s atmosphere, some energy becomes unavailable for ecosystems as this energy is absorbed by inorganic matter or reflected back into the atmosphere.

C178FE24F919434A91B69D67A07C8DE5.description: Explain the impact of a persistent or non-biodegradable pollutant in an ecosystem.

CA6ACC8CF9DB4CA8880FEBEFDC17A93B.description: Explain the relevance of the laws of thermodynamics to the flow of energy through ecosystems.

FE449928607D4F8C92E008C132A017B5.description: Construct system diagrams representing photosynthesis and respiration.

C3AC9E4019E3407A925BA65406C36F59.description: Analyse the efficiency of energy transfers through a system.

46ADC592F1054ECAA3413DFB61C0E1E3.description: Explain the transfer and transformation of energy as it flows through an ecosystem.

40C0804FF4014047A61D4E1DCB478991.description: Construct models of feeding relationships—such as food chains, food webs and ecological pyramids—from given data.

9434469EF8AB4329910586EE4C1FFF95.description: Pyramids of productivity for entire ecosystems over a year always show a decrease along the food chain.

9BBFB339A8A14DEEA74B8F13C12FD796.description: Pyramids of productivity refer to the flow of energy through a trophic level, indicating the rate at which that stock/storage is being generated.

30CD068D5A29458B9B7E80261E9C12D7.description: Pyramids of biomass can show greater quantities at higher trophic levels because they represent the biomass present at a fixed point in time, although seasonal variations may be marked.

7CAC9BFDCDEC4BCC8E874E7FD1B0E6AE.description: A pyramid of biomass represents the standing stock or storage of each trophic level, measured in units such as grams of biomass per square metre (g m–2) or Joules per square metre (J m-2)(units of biomass or energy).

2EFD44412C574FCBAEEF86B205C82C4E.description: Pyramids of numbers can sometimes display different patterns; for example, when individuals at lower trophic levels are relatively large (inverted pyramids).

3F3901FED86547508AD03E164117F739.description: Toxins such as DDT and mercury accumulate along food chains due to the decrease of biomass and energy.

F40AC0DBA1A344E1B89CEF63F2DD45E9.description: Biomagnification is the increase in concentration of persistent or non-biodegradable pollutants along a food chain.

AA1BDD49D0904EC2BD5573D14683A108.description: Bioaccumulation is the build-up of persistent or non-biodegradable pollutants within an organism or trophic level because they cannot be broken down.

8F38B15A7AAD4726A7165B2A84697306.description: In accordance with the second law of thermodynamics, there is a tendency for numbers and quantities of biomass and energy to decrease along food chains; therefore, the pyramids become narrower towards the apex.

EC1A677CFB3F4949B28D71F864E36FEB.description: Ecological pyramids include pyramids of numbers, biomass and productivity and are quantitative models that are usually measured for a given area and time.

A443868B520D46D28647E4138301A433.description: Feeding relationships involve producers, consumers and decomposers. These can be modelled using food chains, food webs and ecological pyramids.

E9627F2B69A842F69DC4F7A8A92B33DC.description: Producers (autotrophs) are typically plants or algae that produce their own food using photosynthesis and form the first trophic level in a food chain. Exceptions include chemosynthetic organisms that produce food without sunlight.

F368232A591141EAADE75ABC1C01C911.description: The trophic level is the position that an organism occupies in a food chain, or the position of a group of organisms in a community that occupy the same position in food chains.

878730C941E5450D929AED640AC1E55E.description: Photosynthesis produces the raw material for producing biomass.

3197DC99AC774AB5AEFAB24B8D96DEC0.description: The photosynthesis reaction is can be represented by the following word equation. carbon dioxide + water → glucose + oxygen

89E5DE2ABC924260838630412DA8AE4A.description: Primary producers in most ecosystems convert light energy into chemical energy in the process of photosynthesis.

3F81160AAA18492180343E644C765CF1.description: During respiration, large amounts of energy are dissipated as heat, increasing the entropy in the ecosystem while enabling organisms to maintain relatively low entropy and so high organization.

94AA4C6F6BFC4402AA74026C7AEB8BF3.description: Respiration is the conversion of organic matter into carbon dioxide and water in all living organisms, releasing energy. Aerobic respiration can be represented by the following word equation. glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water

1132C10940F441CEB1CEF18A5397551A.description: Respiration and photosynthesis can be described as processes with inputs, outputs and transformations of energy and matter.

21C9BACD8E7643608F5DFA7FCB1EF978.description: An ecosystem is a community and the physical environment with which it interacts.

F3577833A66143CAB23AE77B1856FDA5.description: A community is a group of populations living and interacting with each other in a common habitat.

4115CAED0BBC4D24B1FC0AA03B819102.description: Explain population growth curves in terms of numbers and rates.

2BE5C964F89E4651A8E9945E369841ED.description: Interpret graphical representations or models of factors that affect an organism’s niche. Examples include predator–prey relationships, competition, and organism abundance over time.

305DE7B103D94C38AEAFE2EDF5556A92.description: Limiting factors will slow population growth as it approaches the carrying capacity of the system.

F81689ED1DBA426389B27DEBAE71A503.description: S and J population curves describe a generalized response of populations to a particular set of conditions (abiotic and biotic factors).

0823444EB7CE44D7AFEDD8945EBE41DF.description: A population is a group of organisms of the same species living in the same area at the same time, and which are capable of interbreeding.

3BC5408516144C3FB7FFD2D52EE0552A.description: Interactions should be understood in terms of the influences each species has on the population dynamics of others, and upon the carrying capacity of the others’ environment.

3C897D87F8024515891EE5883F3D4AF8.description: The interactions between the organisms—such as predation, herbivory, parasitism, mutualism, disease, and competition—are termed biotic factors.

5345EF11BF38479A947CFDBE17F30578.description: The non-living, physical factors that influence the organisms and ecosystem—such as temperature, sunlight, pH, salinity, and precipitation—are termed abiotic factors.

6B704450171D48ADA23E9C99C8227144.description: The fundamental niche describes the full range of conditions and resources in which a species could survive and reproduce. The realized niche describes the actual conditions and resources in which a species exists due to biotic interactions.

E27CA8B248F643459FE4BF4A05F0A2F6.description: A niche describes the particular set of abiotic and biotic conditions and resources to which an organism or population responds.

421D66C0C8FF438A8EB221AD7EF4E6DB.description: A habitat is the environment in which a species normally lives.

383E6FB01DEC425DB784179DD23AAF49.description: A species is a group of organisms that share common characteristics and that interbreed to produce fertile offspring.

A4FE2651476D4E17950445D9327D7D93.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of each of the three different levels of intervention, with reference to figure 3.

ACB01F66204349768B56FD29F7765160.description: Construct systems diagrams to show the impact of pollutants.

10DBE8302E304F349FBFDF7260FEE1EC.description: Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) exemplifies a conflict between the utility of a “pollutant” and its effect on the environment.

FCD29DA02B284AFEAE03762E11B00F01.description: Pollutants may be primary (active on emission) or secondary (arising from primary pollutants undergoing physical or chemical change).

41A6D697044F4F6DA0AA3245404982B1.description: Pollution may be non-point or point source, persistent or biodegradable, acute or chronic.

FE3DC4E418E14A37AFEDF21FCF765DF9.description: Pollutants may be in the form of organic or inorganic substances, light, sound or thermal energy, biological agents or invasive species, and may derive from a wide range of human activities including the combustion of fossil fuels.

227360894CE949BCB99ADA0680B1DC7F.description: Pollution is the addition of a substance or an agent to an environment through human activity, at a rate greater than that at which it can be rendered harmless by the environment, and which has an appreciable effect on the organisms in the environment.

F7C53D1211474D309BEF7026C5B7507B.description: Explain the relationship between EFs and sustainability.

03F286A2825048D18122414DB8CDCE7E.description: Discuss how environmental indicators such as MA can be used to evaluate the progress of a project to increase sustainability.

2D641879FA9E463A93AE79E2CB462E8D.description: Discuss the value of ecosystem services to a society.

3B49B4A5FFD246B39555C301FC28C669.description: Explain the relationship between natural capital, natural income and sustainability.

571CC1F902844CEFA12298B172A5E5E7.description: An ecological footprint (EF) is the area of land and water required to provide all resources and assimilate all the waste for a given population. If the EF is greater than the area of land and water available to that population, then it is not sustainable.

7196B70AFA7B49D2ADA20FFDF1FC30CE.description: Criticisms of EIAs include: the lack of a standard practice or training for practitioners, the lack of a clear definition of system boundaries and the lack of inclusion of indirect impacts.

A9B00CC76092438983BF6295A7138F3F.description: EIAs provide decision-makers with information in order to consider the environmental impact of a project. There is not necessarily a requirement to implement an EIA’s proposals, and many socio-economic factors may influence the decisions made

565A52DDDAD0499B90B2394F02874B61.description: EIAs incorporate baseline studies before a development project is undertaken. They assess the environmental, social and economic impacts of the project, predicting and evaluating possible impacts and suggesting mitigation strategies for the project. They are usually followed by an audit and continued monitoring. Each country or region has different guidance on the use of EIAs.

2A56A9F5011C4EC3806C5FB69787BE3A.description: Factors such as biodiversity, pollution, population or climate may be used quantitatively as environmental indicators of sustainability. These factors can be applied on a range of scales, from local to global. The Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MA) gave a scientific appraisal of the condition and trends in the world’s ecosystems and the services they provide using environmental indicators, as well as the scientific basis for action to conserve and use them sustainably.

A049641739AF48BE9B0A5D323E6E9E8A.description: Ecosystems may provide life-supporting services such as water replenishment, flood and erosion protection, and goods such as timber, fisheries, and agricultural crops.

AF90BAEB9F32479C8EC5C1BF03FF05E4.description: Natural income is the yield obtained from natural resources.

A823E3B125084DD6A6767466A6C1E91D.description: Natural capital is a term used for natural resources that can produce a sustainable natural income of goods or services.

7D56BF30105C49BAB7CBEDDE81F6122D.description: Sustainability is the use and management of resources that allows full natural replacement of the resources exploited and full recovery of the ecosystems affected by their extraction and use.

89A48C6320D64EAB808D3D3609BC0AEC.description: Evaluate the possible consequences of tipping points.

053C97BCED25420993DAFA81123275DA.description: Discuss resilience in a variety of systems.

C58F696C91494E40BAB11DE9F445B1E6.description: Explain the implications of the laws of thermodynamics to ecological systems.

5D662A70274D4580981B50373FD427C9.description: The delays involved in feedback loops make it difficult to predict tipping points and add to the complexity of modelling systems.

5FB4BB624FFB48DBBE6D04FA6C05E3B5.description: Humans can affect the resilience of systems through reducing these storages and diversity.

5B3CCFC1ABCD47E189094C9E3EEEA502.description: Diversity and the size of storages within systems can contribute to their resilience and affect their speed of response to change (time lags).

2D13F9C6D9BA46C8B5FF39976C8E2A68.description: The resilience of a system, ecological or social, refers to its tendency to avoid such tipping points and maintain stability.

F6D420DE7D814E26AB21956AF82BD521.description: Positive feedback loops (destabilizing) will tend to amplify changes and drive the system towards a tipping point where a new equilibrium is adopted.

5BB374B421C0412E91B075F514E2BE7A.description: Negative feedback loops (stabilizing) occur when the output of a process inhibits or reverses the operation of the same process in such a way as to reduce change—it counteracts deviation.

F4E28F6A7D2F4EA9BB3FC12EA310F181.description: As an open system, an ecosystem will normally exist in a stable equilibrium, either in a steady-state equilibrium or in one developing over time (for example, succession), and maintained by stabilizing negative feedback loops.

732426BFEA12465280738DE606FAA7D8.description: The second law of thermodynamics explains the inefficiency and decrease in available energy along a food chain and energy generation systems.

F4CA1522B59B4505A7E1EF2D7490147F.description: The second law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of a system increases over time. Entropy is a measure of the amount of disorder in a system. An increase in entropy arising from energy transformations reduces the energy available to do work.

AFC14DF38DDF4FA692E1C0713F474A0F.description: The principle of conservation of energy can be modelled by the energy transformations along food chains and energy production systems.

3063585FD27E4417B96AE32C49ECC3F9.description: The first law of thermodynamics is the principle of conservation of energy, which states that energy in an isolated system can be transformed but cannot be created or destroyed.

29EF94E9FAE24741BF7579F691D1ECE3.description: Evaluate the use of models as a tool in a given situation, for example, climate change predictions.

B1052B0712AE40928C8109F9218031E1.description: Construct a system diagram or a model from a given set of information.

6BE8604797DC43A983BA46D20314F88C.description: A model inevitably involves some approximation and therefore loss of accuracy.

2F06CA0DCF3B4DDD8A412EDE53BD9E20.description: A model is a simplified version of reality and can be used to understand how a system works and to predict how it will respond to change.

68C591FBFFDD4BEFB435D6E3169B9960.description: Ecosystems are open systems; closed systems only exist experimentally, although the global geochemical cycles approximate to closed systems.

6792ED4E115D4E15803B3ABCCC5E7C88.description: An isolated system is a hypothetical concept in which neither energy nor matter is exchanged across the boundary.

8132FF64DCAD48E3A294489EB2280A12.description: An open system exchanges both energy and matter across its boundary while a closed system exchanges only energy across its boundary.

E8851E55021742828E7A31F80674A13F.description: In system diagrams, storages are usually represented as rectangular boxes and flows as arrows, with the direction of each arrow indicating the direction of each flow. The size of the boxes and the arrows may be representative of the size/magnitude of the storage or flow.

09493E94F41A41AC87FD4846BA94C498.description: The flows are processes that may be either transfers (a change in location) or transformations (a change in the chemical nature, a change in state or a change in energy).

859E48C68CAE4E779B6842207BEA7D78.description: The flows provide inputs and outputs of energy and matter.

2C280DDB852541EEAC072F1C3FF0056F.description: A system is comprised of storages and flows.

C6682553CC4A4C1DAB52B8EC2EE82CA9.description: The concept of a system can be applied at a range of scales.

53DCD25443874A1CAB525D6C1F35A11D.description: These interactions produce the emergent properties of the system.

B8CA80E6AAB8450E86324F90A18F3B9C.description: A systems approach is a way of visualizing a complex set of interactions which may be ecological or societal.

EF2D6ECBC3E44AC0905419250E1CD546.description: Justify, using examples and evidence, how historical influences have shaped the development of the modern environmental movement.

B3512733A23943CDAEC11658F473C1E7.description: Evaluate the implications of two contrasting EVSs in the context of given environmental issues.

AA5FB2D1EEC841FCA835E39AEE38E069.description: Discuss the view that the environment can have its own intrinsic value.

06B3D379AAA1484391F38697B5957A5E.description: Different EVSs ascribe different intrinsic value to components of the biosphere.

A6433C4D30CF49CB9B8A21C997106541.description: There are extremes at either end of this spectrum (for example, deep ecologists–ecocentric to cornucopian–technocentric), but in practice, EVSs vary greatly depending on cultures and time periods, and they rarely fit simply or perfectly into any classification.

2CE2C0E329C64977A6C69BEF47C1A5F7.description: A technocentric viewpoint argues that technological developments can provide solutions to environmental problems. This is a consequence of a largely optimistic view of the role humans can play in improving the lot of humanity. Scientific research is encouraged in order to form policies and to understand how systems can be controlled, manipulated or changed to solve resource depletion. A pro-growth agenda is deemed necessary for society’s improvement.

1F3473732C84490B91775FD4E7E2DE18.description: An anthropocentric viewpoint argues that humans must sustainably manage the global system. This might be through the use of taxes, environmental regulation and legislation. Debate would be encouraged to reach a consensual, pragmatic approach to solving environmental problems.

2CA859CD0E784F7AB92E4C54A4C392F0.description: An ecocentric viewpoint integrates social, spiritual and environmental dimensions into a holistic ideal. It puts ecology and nature as central to humanity and emphasizes a less materialistic approach to life with greater self-sufficiency of societies. An ecocentric viewpoint prioritizes biorights, emphasizes the importance of education and encourages self-restraint in human behaviour.

BCFD3D1B8F534509B972D24FB5F91E4E.description: There is a spectrum of EVSs, from ecocentric through anthropocentric to technocentric value systems.

2096032D41CD431DB129325C656DF982.description: An EVS might be considered as a system in the sense that it may be influenced by education, experience, culture and media (inputs), and involves a set of interrelated premises, values and arguments that can generate consistent decisions and evaluations (outputs).

105F7F20E9EB4D8B9B4BEE20FC1DE694.description: An EVS is a worldview or paradigm that shapes the way an individual, or group of people, perceives and evaluates environmental issues, influenced by cultural, religious, economic and sociopolitical contexts.

A0E3200FF77947E4B6D3B6DBCE055C81.description: Significant historical influences on the development of the environmental movement have come from literature, the media, major environmental disasters, international agreements and technological developments.

EA1154CED4384D1AAF9B92AE8D0E6344.description: Foundations of environmental systems and societies
